pullrequest.title: Improved FITS support, with a number of small additional refinements

content.raw:
Very impressive number of fixes in this PR.  Hard to test each and every one of them, but I can vouch that #6 from the list above is fixed in this PR (see demo in the Issue description).  That said, I tried to test #5 from the list above and I found some problems.

When I test out this script:
http://paste.yt-project.org/show/5186/

I get two very different results between off-axis and on-axis projections using the 'sum' method:

on_axis_projection: http://i.imgur.com/NIdtAX6.png
off_axis_projection: http://i.imgur.com/AzaIbrN.png

I think the main issue is that the units are different between the two methods: on-axis = g/cm^3, off-axis = g/cm^2.  For a sum projection, I would expect things to be g/cm^3, since we're not dividing by dl, right?
content.html:
Very impressive number of fixes in this PR. Hard to test each and every one of them, but I can vouch that #6 from the list above is fixed in this PR (see demo in the Issue description). That said, I tried to test #5 from the list above and I found some problems.

When I test out this script: http://paste.yt-project.org/show/5186/

I get two very different results between off-axis and on-axis projections using the 'sum' method:

on_axis_projection: http://i.imgur.com/NIdtAX6.png off_axis_projection: http://i.imgur.com/AzaIbrN.png

I think the main issue is that the units are different between the two methods: on-axis = g/cm^3, off-axis = g/cm^2. For a sum projection, I would expect things to be g/cm^3, since we're not dividing by dl, right?

pullrequest.title: Improved FITS support, with a number of small additional refinements

content.raw:
I think the root issue was that the image object didn't have any units,
which means converting to cm or something will keep the same issues as
before.
content.html: I think the root issue was that the image object didn't have any units, which means converting to cm or something will keep the same issues as before.

pullrequest.title: Improved FITS support, with a number of small additional refinements

content.raw: Part of this PR adds units to the image object, however. I'm looking into @chummels's issue.
content.html: Part of this PR adds units to the image object, however. I'm looking into chummels's issue.

pullrequest.title: Improved FITS support, with a number of small additional refinements

content.raw:
Regarding @chummels's note above about `"sum"` projections, I think that we should probably note that it doesn't really work well for AMR datasets, as you end up getting the artifacts that you see above. `"sum"` was originally designed for unigrid FITS datasets where this isn't an issue. This is something I should more clearly document. 

However, the units in the `OffAxisProjectionPlot` are wrong, so I'll fix them.
content.html:
Regarding chummels's note above about "sum" projections, I think that we should probably note that it doesn't really work well for AMR datasets, as you end up getting the artifacts that you see above. "sum" was originally designed for unigrid FITS datasets where this isn't an issue. This is something I should more clearly document.

However, the units in the OffAxisProjectionPlot are wrong, so I'll fix them.

pullrequest.title: Improved FITS support, with a number of small additional refinements

content.raw: Yeah, this makes sense.  As long as the units are aligned and it is documented not to use the 'sum' method for AMR, I think we're fine on this point.  Thank you for looking into this, @jzuhone .
content.html: Yeah, this makes sense. As long as the units are aligned and it is documented not to use the 'sum' method for AMR, I think we're fine on this point. Thank you for looking into this, John ZuHone .

content.raw:
I tested point #9, and it works great!  Nice!!

Also, I tried getting the `mu` to render properly (point #8), but it doesn't seem to work for me.  Here is my sample script:

http://paste.yt-project.org/show/5187/

And the axis labels, which should be in micropc, are just upc:

http://i.imgur.com/bLUzcVu.png

Or is this not how it was supposed to work?

pullrequest.title: Improved FITS support, with a number of small additional refinements

description:
My apologies that this turned into a veritable kitchen-sink PR, but as I was going through and implementing these things I kept finding stuff that needed to be addressed. 

1. Additions to `PPVCube`, including thermal line broadening and allowing for the spectral axis to be in units other than velocity (energy, frequency, or wavelength). Updated docs to reflect these new options.

2. `FITSImageBuffer` (for writing FITS images) had a bewildering and confusing number of options, mainly centered around the writing of WCS coordinates to the file. I've simplified these. Updated the parts of the code that use `FITSImageBuffer` to reflect these changes.

3. Improved options for customizing the center, width, and resolution of FITS images produced with `FITSSlice` and `FITSProjection`.

4. The FITS frontend now recognizes PPV/spectral cubes that have the position axes in length units (previously it was just angular units). In the course of fixing this I had to touch `PlotWindow` just a smidge to make sure that in this case that the appropriate length units appear on the axes of the plots.

5. Added the `"sum"` method to off-axis projections. Partially resolves [this issue](https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/issue/911/enable-the-same-projection-methods-for).

6. Get units correct for off-axis projections. Closes Issue #892. 

7. Raise an error if one attempts to load a FITS file but doesn't have AstroPy installed. Closes Issue #932.

8. Make the micro prefix "u" render as the LaTeX "\mu" in plots. 

9. A new option for specifying plot centers (or anything that uses `sanitize_center`), where you can say you want the min or max of a specific field to be the center. An example:

```
#!python

import yt
ds = yt.load("GasSloshing/sloshing_nomag2_hdf5_plt_cnt_0100")
slc = yt.SlicePlot(ds, "z", "density", center=("min","temperature"))
```
UPDATE: Responded to @ngoldbaum and @chummels's suggestions and bug discoveries--I think I managed to fix all of the issues you found.
